Staff is polite and friendly, food is great,  but management has set policies which I disagree with. 

Grab my meal to go, my friends had food from the food court and so we weren't allowed to sit inside.  Easy to solve, just sit in the food court.  No big deal. 

What is upsetting to me is paying full price, but not getting soup because it's "dine in only". 
Give me the full product, or charge a reduced rate. It's not ok to charge full price.
author: Alex-yelp Y.

description:
Another great little restaurant in the Metro Station close to Moscone Center.  In town for a convention, I had the pleasure of trying some of food in this food court area.  

This was my favorite.  An actually wait to be seated restaurant.  The service was excellent.  The seaweed salad is a must have.   We had an assortment of sushi and it was all good.
author: Brenda D.

description:
For the price this place is kind of a gold mine. I had the salmon roll and two other things that were on the special list. It was fantastic, the texture and taste of the fish was beyond what I was expecting for the price point. There's not much else to say about this place, the service is mediocre, the ambiance is pretty much what you would expect from a place in an upscale mall.  

While I'm sure there is better sushi in SF, this is a great option if you want bang for your buck.
author: Shayla G.

description:
This place is legit. One of the best Curry Udon and Cold Udon in the area.
Sashimi is always fresh. Just come on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays for the freshest fish, those are the delivery days.
Prices are descent, kind of pricey, but I imagine it's because of the location and rent prices. Sashimi salad is a good bang for your buck if you feel for something " healthy".
Service is good, hardly ever a wait. Which is a plus in my book!
author: Kay H.

description:
Nigiri Sushi: standard fish fresh, salmon, maguro, albacore, hamachi. Portions on smaller side, 1/2"x2inches. 

Sesame (Gomae) Spinach salad; too much sugar in dressing. Didn't finish it. 

Sashimi; can substitute. Substituted out mackerel for red snapper. Mackerel is more popular now; harder to eat because of the stronger flavor from the higher fish oil content. 

Veggie/tofu Udon; slightly sweet broth. -1 star for making everything so sweet. 

Service was very good off peak hours. Reasonable price for high rent location. $70.00/dinner for 2.
author: Doug C.

description:
I've been coming here regularly for over a year now and this is massively overdue.

This is hands-down my favorite Japanese place in the city for a few reasons. 

First off, this is convenient. If I'm heading to the Metreon for a movie, I'm definitely eating here.

Secondly, the price is very reasonable, considering the quality of the food.

Third, the menu selection is very wide, and there is plenty to choose from. I also like that they do seasonal dishes, and have a nice selection of Japanese traditional dishes (like the New Year noodles).

All of this pales in comparison to the quality of the fish. I frequently go there to order the Omakase and have Shinji (one of the sushi chefs) explain to me the various fish and their texture.

Overall, I love this place and will keep going back. Most of the poorer reviews generally ate non-sushi sashimi items, or got the usual salmon-tuna stuff. You should come here for something different like the Uni, Kampachi or Aji.. If you want your worn out California roll, go get it from Whole Foods or something.
author: Peter T.

description: Delicious and bonafide.  I recommend it!( okay, if you order sushi with cream cheese, that's your problem!) order the chawanmushi, the nigori sake, the tempura.  The sushi looks good too.
author: F A.

description:
Nabeyaki udon is a must try.
Their California roll is the best and no other restaurant can match it . Sesame chicken is phenomenal . Tempura is perfect.
Can't wait yo come back here again
author: Vischa S.

description:
I work just 2 blocks away, so if I'm craving sushi, I choose Sanraku. 
Decent food, decent service, decent atmosphere. Chicken udon is amazing. 
Rolls are pretty good. 
They even accept reservations at lunch! Pretty good.
author: Luba Y.

description:
Decent place with nice staff. Not too noisy, so you can hold a conversation without shouting.
The beef teriyaki was a bit chewy, but fairly decent. The sashimi were nice and tender.
author: Ventsislav Z.

description: Favorite sushi in SOMA. I know it's in the Metreon, but the rolls taste just as good. My favorites are any of the special rolls that have tempura or eel in them, e.g., Tiger roll. The spicy sesame chicken, though not sushi, is also a favorite. The hot sake there is also very enjoyable.
author: Webb P.

description:
My body wasn't going to take no for an answer. It wanted salmon sashimi and it wanted it now. Thankfully, there's an app to find out where the nearest decent sushi spot can be found in relation to your location. Being located in the financial district on a Sunday meant that a lot of the higher rated sushi restaurants in FiDi were closed. Sanraku was close and open so off we went. 

I ordered the salmon sashimi and salmon donburi bowl to take away. Both were fresh and reasonably flavoured. A perfectly decent takeaway option within the healthier realm.
author: Lani P.

description: The sashimi was fresh (yellow and red tuna) and the service was quick and easy. We also ordered the teriyaki salmon, which was seasoned just right, soft, and tender. Although the cost, $21 for a lunch special, was more than I would normally pay for in the middle of the day, the convenience of quick service balanced out the price. If you need to pick up a quick lunch while on a break, this is a good choice.
author: Karen M.

description: Every thing was tasty.   A little pricey I thought is why giving 4 stars and the location is weird like next to a good court in a mall.   Haha.  But it was good food if near. Give them a shot
author: Brad L.

description: The quality of the food here is amazing. Really good and wide variety of sushi in general, plus the meat is also amazing. The only downside of this place is that it's in a pretty ugly mall, such as the Metreon.
author: Antonio H.

description: One of my favorite lunch places in Soma, I usually come here once/twice a week with my coworkers! Almost all the times we get the bento box! Cheap (price wise), flavorful, delicious, filling, just what you need! Their entrees come with rice, as well as salad and miso soup! Sometimes we also order a roll or two to go with our bento box. My favorite rolls so far: dragon roll, tiger roll, spider roll. They taste great! Very fresh! We usually come before 12PM or after 1PM so the wait isn't too bad. Fast service, great ambiance.
author: Xin W.

description: We came to this restaurant after not being here for a few years snd were pleasantly surprised. The management changed or something but food is much better than i remember it was a few years ago. Sushi rolls taste good, chicken teriaky tasts good. Service is friendly. Now remember that this restaurant is in the movie theater so have realistic expectations and enjoy your food.
author: Kim L.

description: I should have taken the portion size reviews more seriously. Too expensive for what you get. $56 for unagi, uni, salmon roe, hamachi toro, and a rainbow roll. Would have been happy with the price if the sushi portions weren't so small.
author: Jerry T.

description: At the top of my experience today is Ankimo  and Saba. Presented with expertise and in authentic Japanese style. A surprise of various nigiri to finish my meal made this a must here in San Francisco!
author: Bruce B.

description:
Had lunch here today after seeing Ride Along at the theater in the same building

We had the bento box and the tofu dish and it was all good.  The service was nice and prompt.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Finding a spot for lunch around lunchtime proper is enough of a chore in all of the greater San Fran area. Sanraku, you were a nice respite from long lines and lack of indoor seating. Found inside the Metreon, which I like to think is the name of a meteor/robot combo.

Who's going to argue with a Bento Box chockablock full of sesame chicken, salmon, cali rolls, and seaweed salad? Pretty cheap, too. Not a bad combo with miso and a ginger salad on the salad, too. Ginger salad for a ginger dude. Nice pairing, duuuuude. 

Quarters are a little tight. Be careful not to knock over someone holding a tray with your food or another patron's.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
I've been to this place for times in two years, and I think each set of times (2 times in a year), it's played out the same way. 

First the staff is very nice and helpful.  The service is always great and I've never said please and thank you so much in my life during one meal. Everyone is so courteous.

So Trip 1 I go and I get sesame chicken, because It's chicken, and I don't like sushi.  I notice the asterisk that says spicy sauce available.  I think that is probably good, but I go on the safe side, and get the normal sweet sauce.   I enjoy the sweet sauce but regret the lack of heat... so I set out to return for the spicy sauce.  I get the spicy sauce on Trip 2, and it is amazing. It's delicious, and I can't get enough of it. 

This is what happened last year, and this year when I went.  Though last year, I didn't write a yelp review of the experience so I forgot all about actually trying the spicy sauce.  So...  Future Chris, get the spicy sauce. Always get the spicy sauce.
author: Chris M.

description:
Well...after walking around the car show for a couple of hours, we were exhausted and starving.  Sanraku was the closest familiar restaurant we had to choose from.  Okay, we're SO down for some sushi.

Once we were seated and began to look at the menu, we noticed a delicious smell of chili waffing through.  WHERE can we get some?  We were a bit distracted.  The menu at Sanraku is rather limited unfortunately.  We settled on the today's special lunch box (miso soup, tempura vegetables, gyoza, wakame salad, $9.95) and the caterpillar roll ($11).  Hmm...this is pretty pricey.  It better be good.  Everything was mediocre at best.  The tempura was soggy.  My caterpillar roll was small.  I've had much bigger roll elsewhere for around $8-9.  Within 30 minutes, I was hungry again.

We left regretting not tracking down the origins of the chili aroma.  Or going for the cheaper gyro place next door.

I don't remember Sanraku ever being THIS bad...
author: Melinda Y.

description: As much as I hate being in the "stuck" here for work meeting lunches and dinnerse, I have to say that they've consistently delivered in quality and service. It's not a sexy date place by all means but you know, it's pretty good in my book. Decent selection and large enough portions for sushi to keep me happy. Small sakes are affordable without breaking the bank. Solid for a sushi spot in the Metreon.
author: Tiff W.

description: I ate here a few years ago probably under diferent  management and food was much better. Yesterfay i camd here with a colleague and was disappointed. Had couple of orders of rolls and chichen teriyaki. Rolls were ok, chicken did not taste like teriyaki at all. I like their outside sitting with a view of Yerba Buena garden, but they need to change their chef.
author: Pat F.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in San Francisco. The fish is always impeccably fresh and Tomo's masterful presentation and attention to detail make it a cut above the rest.

The Tobiko with Quail egg is not to be missed. The Tuna Zuke and the King Crab roll are also favorites.

The grilled black cod is also a great addition to any meal.

Highly suggest sitting at the sushi bar.
author: Gayle U.

description:
Yay! Their sesame chicken is now back to normal and yummy again! Thank you for fixing this! Although sometimes they give you very little sauce. 

I miss their Wed lunchbox- ebi fry! Please bring it back!

Rolls are still tiny!

Staff is cool.

When I feel like splurging for lunch, and spending more than the usual $8-12 I spend on a sandwich or a burrito, I head to Sanraku. They have a broad menu of delicious Japanese standards, and I can usually get out of there for about $20.

The last time I had lunch at Sanraku, I felt a little cold coming on, so I ordered the tempura soba. Soba is a thin buckwheat noodle, and they serve it in a hot broth with a sizable order of tempura veggies and shrimp on the side. The noodles are chewy and delicious, the broth had some great flavor, and the tempura was fresh and crunchy (except for the broccoli; I think tempura broccoli is just a bad idea in the first place). This is definitely one of my comfort foods, and it helped a lot that day.

The table service is friendly and attentive. They don't seem to skimp on servers, which is nice if you don't have a lot of time for lunch. On sunny days, you can even sit outside and enjoy views of the Yerba Buena Gardens.
author: Andrew M.

description:
The decor and the interior of the restaurant is really nice and clean and it's located right next to the Yerba Buena garden!
We were served right away and the service was really nice and the best part is that the wait time is really fast so the food came right away!
I ordered the sashimi salad, which was unfortunately really small but the sashimi was really fresh and tasty! It was $15+tax, so very pricey and the quality was decent. 
My friend ordered the garlic steak, and it came with a side of salad and a bowl of rice. The steak itself was really thin and it came in a sizzling pan, so if you ordered it rare/medium rare, it ends up cooking by itself... However, the steak was very soft, but not the best steak ever. 
Overall, this wouldn't be a Japanese sushi restaurant that I would come when I'm in SF, especially when there are a lot of other good restaurants.
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots in the city. Everything I've had has been super good. Top of my list of places to go repeatedly.
author: Marc C.

description: I came here twice for work lunches and enjoyed the food both times. We ordered the seaweed salad, the tempura appetizer and a few rolls to share. We had the 49ers, giants, crunch, rainbow and dynamite rolls and the fish all tasted fresh and the portions were good, too. The stuff is friendly and efficient, our water glasses were always filled without us having to ask. I would definitely come here again!
author: Alice W.

description:
This place is solid for a quick, cheap and tasty sushi lunch. 

The specials are off the chain, but I had my own little combo in mind. I ordered up a spicy tuna roll and I have to give their California roll a go, since--well, I was in California. Both were very tasty, nothing super special, but the pickled ginger refills were right on point. LIke many others have mentioned, the food came up super fast, which is key during the lunch rush. I also had a miso soup and it was pretty typical, but also delicious. My other table-mates mostly ordered the bento boxes or combos of other kinds. I will admit that bento looked rather cute. Yes, I just described someone's lunch as cute. 

I wouldn't go as far as rating it up there with some of the higher end sushi places I've tried in San Francisco, but for a speedy, tasty experience that won't break the bank, this place is your jam.
author: Cara L.

description: I'm really really picky with sushi. I loved their sushi, and I even ordered delivery! This will be my go-to place from now on. Hands down the best in San Francisco! I ordered salmi nigiri, Eskimo Roll, and miso... All really good! Their chicken teriyaki is really good too!
author: Giselle R.

description:
I don't get the negative reviews. Very fresh, very good sushi served quick.
The only negative is the theater goers children running up and down the ramp that is open to the restaurant. 
They don't have a sushi sheet to fill out  but you can't beat it for fresh, delicious food.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Food is 3 stars, but rating the restaurant one star because of the very rude receptionist woman meant to give customers seats.

We were two, and a table for two was clean, available, not booked or anything. And she asked us to wait for 10 minutes before seating us with attitude. We asked if the table was booked or anything. She answered that it was not booked or anything, but arrogantly and defiantly said that we had to wait to get that table without giving us any reason for doing so.

She forced us to sit at the bar if we wanted to sit immediately which we did. I asked for the manager, and he had no idea why she did that, and yet did not seem to care at all.

Our waitress was nice, the food was not great but ok. I recommend the restaurant to get another receptionist.
author: Cedrick C.

description:
This is our go-to spot for sushi night. It's priced right and close to the action, located in the Metreon, with a nice dining area. I would give it five stars, but sometimes the service is a little hit-or-miss. I've had fabulous servers with great recommendations and table service, and some that forget orders and never come back to the table.

I usually get a couple rolls, maybe the Giants roll or Dynamite roll. My husband likes to get the sushi or sashimi platter. His goal is to be able to order enough sushi to warrant the chef plating it all on one of those bamboo ship things, but so far he can only eat enough for one human and I think you need to order 4-6 human's worth of sushi for that experience. But, you gotta have goals.  

We usually go on weeknights and have no trouble getting a table for 2-4. Not sure how busy it gets on weekends though, but they do take reservations if you have a show to get to or something.
author: Emily F.

description: Beware: They appear to have some organizational issues.  I just waited for 40 minutes seated at the bar.  I received several apologies from my server, but never received my meal.  I left when she told me 10 more minutes at 40 minutes.  There was never any explanation.  I have no reason to question the positive food reviews they've received, but it's a gamble whether you'll get that food in a timely manner.
author: Kevin M.

description: Great service - very friendly. Fresh fish. Sashimi app was divine. Had the Dynamite roll that was good - neat to watch them make it. The tuna isn't pre seared. They add the sauce then blow torch it. Wine was just ok. Still 5 stars due to all else! May come back later in the week since I have 2 more dinners in town.
author: Marie S.

description: A good spot to grab food before or after a movie if you're looking for something a step up from other options in the Metreon. It was easy to get a spot, service was friendly, and our three sushi rolls were all decent.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Went there specifically to eat sashimi....And I'm very sorry that I picked this place.  Sashimi pieces were so thin, that I could see through!  
I never seeing such a UNgenerous place, as far as fish pieces. 
Service was very so-so.  Prices very high for the amount and quality you get. 
I would not recommend this place to anyone who's looking to eat some sashimi.
author: Katya S.

description: This is our regular haunt. Great food, great service. And Chef Shinji is THE BEST!
author: Anthony B.

description:
Service and food are always good.
I especially love their salmon don and sushi rolls.
author: Lynn H.

description:
Friday night - we made a reservation through the yelp app and got seated right away. The staff was really friendly. 
It is a really relaxed atmosphere with a sushi bar. We sat towards the back and we got the MAGNA and the GIANTS rolls and they were both incredible. Spicy and fresh!!! Our two favorite things. Our waitress was wonderful. And came back to check on us multiple times. Fast service and very attentive!! Best sushi we have had in SF Thus far! We will be back. So wonderful. Good mochi too!!
author: Erica J.

description:
I give it 1 star because of their business practice.  I never ordered out...always eaten in.  On their menu, an entree comes with salad, rice and soup.  Well guess what...you don't get soup if you take out.  Really...poor business practice and cheap.

Their prices are already slightly high and to hold off on soup on take out orders is bad business.

Million dollar question...will I got back.  HELL NO!!!!!!!
author: MickYee M.

description:
I love sushi. And I really love checking out new sushi restaurants when I travel. During my recent trip to San Francisco, I was staying at Intercontinental and Sanraku was a well-rated restaurant close by. 
I ordered rolls for takeout and really liked the service and the food. My order was ready in no time, the rolls were very fresh, with unagi still warm. It came with low sodium soy sauce and a wet towel! 
I was not particularly impressed with their Philadelphia and California rolls but unagi (rock-n-roll) was delicious.
While this is far from the best sushi I've ever had, it is decent and a good value for the money.
author: Maria N.

description: The sushi rolls were fantastic here, and the wait was not bad at all. However, the sashimi was tasteless and mediocre. Most places don't get that right though. But the worst was that the chicken teriyaki was dry and tasteless. That shouldn't be too hard. I would just stick to the rolls next time.
author: Brian C.

description:
Had dinner here while I was up in SF for a conference. We were seated immediately and our server was very friendly. Menu selection was fairly typical with standard American Japanese options and a few specialty rolls that sounded good. There were also several vegetarian options, which was nice as one person in our party was vegetarian.

I got the Garlic Steak entree, the 49'ers roll, and the edamame appetizer. The steak was very tasty and came with one scoop of rice, a cup of miso soup, and a side salad the same size as the soup. I'm glad I ordered the roll because it was definitely on the small side for a dinner. Some of the other reviews mention that their rolls are only six-pieces, but the 49ers roll came with the standard eight. There was thinly sliced lemon on top, complete with seeds, so I had to peel that off to eat it. It would have been fine if there were no seeds and the rind wasn't so thick.

Overall the food was good, but not amazing, and definitely not for the price. I'm assuming the area is just very expensive and the restaurants cater towards businessmen. I'd give 3-4 stars if the meal was in the $15-20 range, but the quality was just too low for a $40 bill before tax/tip.

The entree dishes also came to our table a good 15 minutes before the sushi. We had already completely finished our entrees before the sushi arrived.
author: David A.

description:
In San Fran for a business trip. Came here with a co-worker based upon Yelp reviews. We thought we'd give it a shot since it was close to our hotel and the fact we were hungry for sushi.  

It's located in a food court area, but it's really a restaurant. The staff were all extremely friendly. The service was extremely fast. The sushi was fresh, tasty and reasonably priced. I would definitely come back!
author: Zach C.

description:
My workmate and I came here for lunch. It was packed...with men in suits. We assumed there was a big conference since everyone seemed to look like a million dollar bucks. 

Anyhoo, we had to wait for a while before we were seated to our table. We ordered right way soon as we were seated to not waste our constricted time. Despite that, we manage to punch in some jokes about food based on our experiences with it. 

I have to say that the quality of the fish here is not the best. It didn't smell fishy but texture and color spoke for itself. I ate some baby squids that came with our sashimi lunch. Had sourness and a little sweetness to the sauce that coated it - it tasted good. The Dragon Roll is my least favorite in this place. It's been a while since I ordered dragon but it's one of my fave rolls. As far as I remember it always have shrimp tempura in it. So they didn't have that in it. 

We didn't have a permanent server and it seemed like it applied for everyone there. It can get little chaotic when some other servers come to ask you same questions that the other servers already did because they didn't know that someone already took care of you.
author: Lora M.

description:
This restaurant is inside the METREON in the food court, but the ambiance is nice enough. 

Overall the food is pretty decent.  Out of convenience, I'll eat here right before catching a movie at AMC and it'll hit the spot. I've tried the spider roll, rainbow roll, tenzaru soba, sashimi salad, amaebi, uni.  Everything was pretty good..pretty average I would say.
author: Jenn L.

description:
I'm happy about their new Happy Hour menu, available 3-7pm ($5 or less). I give the new value priced options 4.5 stars rounded up to 5 stars.

Also they replaced the Special Rolls with a dozen very decent choices. The previous tacky pictures taped to the walls, and the weird spicy mayo sauce covered rolls are gone, yes! good decision.

____________

Sometimes I don't know what nonsense other people write on their reviews. Someone mentioned that this place is tiny, compared to what? an aircraft carrier? This place is not tiny, it can hold several groups dining at the same time. The Sutter street location is smaller, but it has a separate large section for private parties, so overall that place is not tiny either.

The wait staff is professional and friendly. This restaurant doesn't get the respect it deserves, because a few customers are out of town noobs who expect to pay Safeway sushi prices, or don't appreciate the skill level of the chef. I'm not saying that it's the best, but it's much better than many other places.
author: Luis C.

description:
Review of an average tuesday night: 

Service friendly and quick.
I like the special rolls, nothing really out of the ordinary. Just good delicious quality sushi. 
Sometimes there's a wait, at other times (such as tonight) you can be seated right away.
We live a block away and come here quite often. Sometimes we take our tourist friends here before watching a movie.
author: Momo M.

description:
My friend John suggested that we go over to Sanraku one day. Rebecca, John and I were out for drinks and I have to admit that I was thinking what? the Metreon? Really? But knowing John, he never steers me wrong. He knows his food and he was right about Sanraku. 

The service was really good and fast. The Sashimi was incredible and they served it in 3's so we didn't have to fight over who gets what. We also ordered a few rolls and some sake. I typically take pictures of my meal, but since everything was super good - I forgot. 

I did however get one picture of the lovely oyster shooters that we had. They were just as tasty as they looked. (Check it out babies!)

I am so sorry that I doubted you before, Sanraku. It's just the Metreon, not exactly the spot for fine dining, but I know now. 

Thanks XOXO, Bekah.
author: Rebekah T.

description: The sushi is pretty good albeit pricey however the service leaves much to be desired!!
author: Ed R.

description: Ume Shiso roll here is amazing. I came two days in a row. Really delicious and fresh... And great service!
author: Tasha H.

description: Impressive for a busy Friday night dinner. As soon as my husband and I sat down we were ready to order. The waitress was prompt and attentive. As soon as we put in our orders she asked us if we were in a hurry. Bonus points for that! We were in no hurry but it's an important question to ask when in the city. I think that was the first time any waitress has asked me that! I ordered the sesame chicken - crispy & sweet, a tad over cooked (meat was slightly dry but barely noticeable). My husband ordered the garlic rib eye steak. It came out on a sizzling platter - pretty standard, soft meat (a plus!), a tad bland so we added soy sauce. Good food, not sure the price reflects but, hey, we're in the city!
author: Trina D.

description:
I've been a loyal Sanraku fan at their Sutter location. Since I've moved, I haven't been back to the Sutter location and was excited to see this option at the Metreon. 

The quality of their sushi remain 4 stars but their kitchen food is just a 2 stars. We were hungry and needed a quick but hefty meal before the movie so we chose their dinner combinations. The steak teriyaki was still good quality but the meat was cold when it arrived our table, the sesame chicken was super over-friend. 

If you visit this Sanraku, skip any kitchen food and only order from their sushi menu and you'll be fine.
author: Maggie C.

description: At first we planned to go to another Sanraku as the app recommends, then we found this one in Metreon quietly. Salmon sashimi is always my favorite. It is really really fresh here!! Love it.
author: Katok K.

description:
I wanted some sushi after the movies and tadah! there is was inside the metreo!
I wasn't expecting much due to its location by the food court, but I would have to say it was better that expected.

Likes:
- nigiri pieces were moderately fresh with good variety. 
- Rolls are nice, decent, but then again it's really hard to go wrong with rolls.

less likes:
- Ankimos are not so great. 

I would visit again before or after movies- it's somewhere you can go for some light sushi/roll cravings.
author: Yoonmi P.

description: Worst service I've had in years. At one point we were considering just getting up and leaving because nobody would bring us a check for THIRTY MINUTES. The food was flavorless as well. Overall a very disappointing experience.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
There seems to be an abundance of 3-star sushi joints in SOMA, and I'll admit when the sashimi craving hits, I'll stoop to a 3-star level to get my fix. Seems crazy, considering that mediocre raw fish could have painful consequences, so I guess that makes me a risk taker. Or just too lazy to walk to a 4-star joint.

Sanraku is tucked within the Metreon building, with a nice view of Yerba Buena garden. Like most sushi joints, the ambience is nothing to marvel at - it's simple, clean, and gets the job done. So, let's talk sushi...

The menu is totally standard, with some bento box lunch specials and your run-of-the-mill rolls. I always have to have my seaweed salad, so I was lured by the special Sanraku seaweed salad, claiming to have 3 different types of seaweed on a bed of greens. For $10, I had high hopes. Yes, it came with 3 types of seaweed, but in measly little portions; the majority of this pricey salad being lettuce, not seaweed. The dressing was more acidic than flavorful, and I couldn't wait for my sushi to arrive...this salad was just not cuttin' it. 

We shared a few of the fancy rolls; you know, the ones that Americans order (with spicy mayo sauce and tempura fried this and that). They were mostly delicious, and definitely filled the sushi void. Service was sporadic (who exactly was our server? We weren't sure), and during the lunch rush that became a problem when we needed to jet back to the office for a meeting. Next time we'll tell them we're on a tight schedule, maybe that'll help.

Pricey sushi, considering the location. But, if you're in the area and in desperate need of rawness, Sanraku can fix you up in an A-OK fashion.
author: Nique F.

description:
Not bad for a Japanese joint in the Metreon food court. 

I expected Sanraku to be either mediocre or overpriced, but was instead pleasantly satisfied. It was a rare nice day in the city so the outdoor tables in view of the park were a great option. 

I got one of the combination bento box and really liked the crispy tempura vegetables and shrimp. The box also had some seaweed salad, pickled vegetables, a well assembled California roll,  and some chicken teriyaki. The chicken was definitely the disappointment of the meal, as it was very dry and was definitely not freshly made. Soup, salad, and rice, are included as well. Overall I was very happy with the variety of things included. Service was attentive and friendly. 

Definitely a decent option in the Metreon food court.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Pretty good sushi, but the location was just okay.  I've eaten at their other locations, and prefer them much more.
It wasn't too chilly out, but we had to eat inside because they didn't have any outdoor heaters.  Inside, even though you're within the bounds of the restaurant, it feels like you're sitting in the food court of the mall.
author: Ian C.

description: It's so convenient here because it's right inside the Metreon. It's never too crowded. Sometimes there's a wait, but you never have to wait long. I wouldn't say their sushi is exceptionally good - their rolls are not as fresh and soft as I'd like them to be. It's also a little pricey for if you just want to get your sushi fix. I'd go here just for convenience, but not if you really want to enjoy some good sushi.
author: Jamie C.

description: Good sushi for Metreon and close distance to Moscone Convention Center. I like their tonkatsu lunch special. A bit pricey and not the best Japanese in the area, but again, it's the convenience that wins here.
author: Peter K.

description: One of the better restaurants in the area. The chicken teriyaki is really good; good sauce and the chicken was cooked perfect with great non fatty pieces. The chocolate mochi was perfect, but the mango piece I had was hard and bad, but maybe it was just an off piece. The food and service is really fast too, they definitely know how to appease their clientele.
author: Adamme K.

description:
I had the bento lunch box, which was just ok, and cost $12. The grilled salmon had no taste, no salt at all, so I had to put lots of soy sauce.  The fried chicken had strong sauce, but the meat was tender.  I was actually surprised that they used chicken breast.  Usually Japanese fried chicken is all dark meat.  

I don't know about dinner menu here, but for quick lunch at food court, I may want to eat something else for more reasonable price.
author: Ann L.

description: Sushi was good enough.  Fish was fresh.  Given their location, I'm surprised they don't step it up a notch.  Service was lackluster.
author: Suzy G.

description:
We have been loyal customers of this place for about two years. The food is excellent, the people who work there have always treated us nicely, and the prices are more than reasonable.

Unfortunately, we won't be going anymore. For some reason (which I suspect is related to a one-time customer who used my vaping as an excuse to demand being comped), they have changed their mind on their longstanding policy of vaping allowed, to vaping prohibited.

Because Sanraku chose to please the customer trying to scam them over my regular loyal business, in effect I must choose between Sanraku and vaping.  I choose vaping.

If you enjoy good sushi and you don't vape, I recommend Sanraku. If you vape, there are other places to go.
author: Manuel A.

description:
This place has some great lunch specials. And a lot of babies! 

No babies on the menu, but quite a number of families were dining here with their toddlers and the restaurant seemed very accommodating.

Lunch specials ranged between $9 - $14 and came brimming with good and plenty of food. I personally ordered the Combination Lunch which come with your choice of:

4 pieces of nigiri, 5 pieces of sashimi, or 6 pieces of California Roll served with miso soup and steamed rice with chicken terriyaki. 

The chef's choice of nigiri on this particular day included cuts of salmon, tuna, shrimp and yellow tail. The sushi was solid, but not pretty standard.  The chicken was a little overcooked, but the flavor delicately sweet and savory and tasted delicious over the perfectly cooked rice. Additionally, there was a lush salad served adjacently topped with a light vinaigrette dressing.

Although I was not incredibly hungry to start with, I was able to polish off almost everything and yet managed not to feel bloated or weighed down after the fact. It was an incredibly filling, light lunch.

I'd definitely come back, although it would not be my first choice or a huge rec I'd throw out to someone unless they were in the neighborhood and looking for a quick fix! The food itself would round out to about a 3.5 rating but the lunch specials are such a great bargain that Sanraku pulled a soy sauced 4 stars out of my chopsticks.
author: Tara L.

description: Better than typical food-court fare, Sanraku is consistently decent. An elegant pre-movie meal that will leave you feeling nourished.
author: Be F.

description: Conveniently located in the Metreon food court so it's great for a work lunch.  Sushi (all I've tried) is fresh and delicious BUT it is quite pricey for the ambiance and portions you get.
author: C W.

description:
Food is not bad, particularly given the other options in the Metreon, but I wouldn't go without being in the area first.

If you're a vegetarian, double check ingredients - some of the noodle bowls come with meat.
author: Olivier L.

description:
Happy hour deals are great! Sit at the bar!

Strange location in a mall that is under construction, but very good sushi. Excellent chefs. Plenty of happy hour specials on both sushi and drinks.
author: David B.

description:
Cheap restaurant actually. We got a teriyaki chicken, tofu udon soup, spicy tuna, spicy yellowtail for like 40 something bucks. Really good prices and the food was filling and fresh.

Attentive staff, clean restaurant.
author: Jennifer S. C.

description: 3.5 stars. I love the Sanraku on Sutter so I thought I'd give this location a try. The servers and sushi chefs were so nice, but I was only meh about the food. Their uni wasn't as fresh as the Sutter location. Overall I'd come back here for sushi if I'm watching a movie and craving sushi. The people that work at this location are sooo nice though so props to them!
author: Portia G.

description:
I've given this place four stars only because of its odd location in a narrow section off the food court of a mall. The food deserves five stars. Every roll and sashimi that we ordered was perfectly prepared and melted in our mouths. Unfortunately my 10 and 8 year olds loved it as much as my husband and I did so we were fighting over food. 
The service was great. Several waitstaff continually surveyed the tables and we had drinks and additional food ordered and served quickly. We made reservations on OpenTable 20 minutes ahead of time which got us in right away. We watched several other parties wait for a while for a table so I highly recommend a reservation.
author: Tracy S.

description: expensive. worst rib eye (teriyaki) ever. dry and tough and not tasty. had the lunch set with veg tempura for 20. large portions but I wouldn't eat it again. veg tempura was French beans  (!), huge chunks of cauliflower (yuck) and broccoli (meh), carrot, sweet potato and eggplant (best). my 3 year old only ate white rice. sigh. maybe sushi is better but was afraid to eat it due to low health score. disappointing
author: pj n.

description:
The pieces of nigiri and sashimi were okay. 

Unfortunately the wasabi had no spiciness, it felt very bland. Even undiluted, we ate chunks of that stuff and felt nothing in our noses. 

The other meals are looking more interesting.
author: Nicolas R.

description:
While visiting friends who live in the greater San Francisco area, we decided to make Saturday evening sushi dinner plans.  Despite note being a local, they trusted me to find a place  (and I really wanted to make sure we could get a reservation because there was six of us).  Combining Open Table and Yelp I was able to find this spot and got a table at 7:15pm.  According to my SF friends, finding a reservation the same day in downtown SF on a Saturday is virtually impossible, so I was pleased I was able to accomplish this.  

I am a lover of sushi and have had everything from low grade to high class sushi.  It always amuses me when people expect $$$$ quality sushi and only pay $$.  I felt this restaurant had a nice balance of good quality and good price.  

When we were initially seated I pointed to the bottle of "Cherry Blossom" sake and told the waiter I would like to order a bottle.  He hesitated and told me "the price on the menu is just for one glass."  I nodded and stated "I am aware."  He then hesitated again and said "the price for a bottle is a lot more," to which I responded "I am certainly expecting that."  For the size of the bottle we got (and trust me it was HUGE..more than enough for all six of us to have 3-4 rounds) I expected to pay $150-$200 for the bottle.  Turns out to *only* be $130.  Very nice.  I guess the server is not used to people buying a whole bottle because no sooner did I order it we had a different server.  Oh well, his loss and her gain.

One of my friends and I ordered and shared the Fisherman's Miso.  Think miso soup meets chunks of fish meat and muscles.  Very tasty, but not for someone who doesn't like fish, because the broth was extremely fishy.  The fish still had bones inside, too so be careful when you eat it.

The rolls were delicious.  I personally ordered the Tiger roll, Spider roll, the 101 roll, and the San Francisco roll.  Everyone at the table ordered different things and everyone had nothing but positive things to say about what they ordered.  The use of perilla in the rolls made for a delicious change in what I am used to when I order standard rolls such as Tiger.  

If you are coming here with a party larger than five I highly recommend getting a reservation so they can be ready for you.  Most sushi places are not equip for larger parties so it makes it easier for them when they know you are coming to push tables together.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: If I could give it 0 stars, I surely would. Made a reservation for 8 and they told me they're running 10 minutes behind. No problem, right? Wrong. 840 rolls around and we still haven't been seated. I had a 10 pm show to catch so we ended up leaving. Here's a tip for you Sanraku: honor the reservations you take, or don't take them at all.
author: Scott W.

description: I was in heaven at lunch here. The over-poured sake (hey, it's Saturday), the excellent miso, and the sushi-sashimi chef's selections were all homeruns. I know nothing about sake so the over-pour confused me. I googled what to do.
author: Pierre Trudeau I.

description:
Good quality sushi in SOMA. The place is clean and cute with good ambience. The food came out quickly and was very tasty.
One of the best sushi places in SOMA probably with reasonable price.
Definitely going back.
author: Haleh H.

description: I have not been here in a long time and used to really like this restaurant.  It feels like the food is not as good as I remember it and the service was mediocre.  The sushi and sashimi was good and the udon was decent, but the chicken teriyaki was mediocre -- kind of overcooked and chewy.  If the service was a bit better and the food back to what it used to be, it could be a 4.5 in my book.
author: Ed J.

description: Great food and downright amazing service.  I travel and eat at restaurants a lot.  I've never seen such an organized staff.  It was like watching a well oiled machine.  Fast clearing of plates, quick with refills and check. Just the way a business lunch should be.  Loved the Curry Don with Katsu.
author: Chris B.

description: NOT VEGETARIAN FRIENDLY. I know it's a sushi restaurant but most are pretty accommodating. Here they had a bunch of seemingly vegetarian tofu entrees only to discover they are all made with shrimp sauce. Many of their seemingly veggie rolls also had shrimp paste or sauce in them. It wouldn't take much to be accommodating to veggie folks, so this experience was very disappointing. I guess I'll have two orders of the daikon radish rolls, please?
author: Devanshu P.

description:
We came here with a group of 13 friends for a birthday party.  The sake was great, and the sushi, for most part, was right on the money.  

As far as the appetizers go, I strongly suggest the pickles. They were very yummy, and so unique.  

I enjoyed almost every roll, and thought they were all well made, fresh, and quite delicious. Unfortunately, I don't remember what my favorite roll was, but it had a thin slice of lemon on top... so yeah I guess I'm suggesting you go there and ask for the one with lemon on it! (Yup I'm nailing this review truly huh?)
author: Moozhan T.

description:
Back in my good graces! After a couple recent visits, this is surely one of the more solid, reliable, enjoyable sushi restaurants in town. Don't mind that it's in a food court, it's got the prime location, secluded on the edge so it's private, big windows facing the park outside, and on warm days, outdoor seating for lunch (so you can bring your dog, how many sushi places are dog friendly?)

Sanraku has survived more or less unchanged for 20 years as the surrounding building, neighborhood, and entire city have undergone multiple transitions. It is still very Japanese in body and attitude (nearly everyone here is Japanese, which is not common in San Francisco), everyone is helpful and knowledgeable, they work very hard, and there is a lot of attention to details. The menu is quite large, with a greatest hits parade of standard Japanese fare -- soba, udon, tonkatsu, all the well-known appetizers, nigiri, rolls, two kinds of kama (hamachi and salmon), and an extensive menu of fish specials. You would have to dine here about ten times, with friends, before you had the run of the menu. So far, everything in this year's visits has been hearty and satisfying -- the soup broth made of shrimp shells, nicely cooked (non-homemade) soba noodles, perfectly-done tempura with high quality shrimp and broccoli, that scourge of American tempura.

Price-wise, the sushi is more expensive than average ($26 or $32 for chirashi deluxe, I forget which), but everything else is a good value. Fortunately, the non-sushi dishes are all well made, so you can have a modest priced large meal here, and splurge with a few special sushi items if you wish.

With the City's most popular movie theater upstairs, it is a real treat to be able to have good sushi before or after your movie, and now that the park outside has such a fantastic free music and performance program, it makes it into a one-building date.
author: Gil S.

description: Not bad for being inside the Metreon. I honestly didn't expect the fish on the nigiri to be so generous. Sushi was fresh and delicious. While the sanraku in tendeloin may be better, this place is hard to beat for the location. I would definitely come back.
author: Nancy Z.

description: My wife and I enjoy coming here. The food is good (not great), and overall atmosphere is pleasant... Due to the location, they cater to the business community, so it's not a spot I would recommend for a "romantic date". There are no restrooms available to public, and check this out: "Due to the recent drought in California, the customer can order water OR tea, but not both!" At first I thought the server was joking, but soon realized he was not... Hilarious!!!
author: JonJon W.

description:
The experience started off terrible.  We put our names down for two.  Great we're second on the list behind another couple.  Another couple walks up to the hostess, asks her how long is the wait for two.  She replies, "Oh no wait.  Do you want a table or sushi bar?"  She takes the couple on the list in front of us and the newly arriving couple to their seats.  My wife asked how about us, we're on the list.  The hostess says they were here first.  She points at us and says you're next.  Of course we are.  We're the only ones left.  WTF?  

We get seated and the waitress was really prompt.  We order a Ten Don and Beef Curry Don along with an Agedashi Tofu.  Tofu had no flavor in the dashi broth.  The Beef curry don was okay.  The ten don was drenched in tempura sauce.  The tempura was soggy and was a mess.  We ate what we could, left a crappy tip and left.  

Go to the Sutter Street location instead, at least they know how to treat customers.
author: Stan V.

description:
I really liked the food here.  Its busy during lunch hour.  

Nothing special about the foods we ordered but I liked the ambiance. Right inside there is a new food court for movie watchers too. 

Curry udon for our little toddler
Salmon skin Roll 
Salmon Dobouri
author: Jboogie L.

description:
This sushi restaurant is located in the Yerba Buena shopping center. I came here after work with a friend and thought the food was really good. We ordered the following: 

Chirashi - bowl of variety of raw fish or seafood. It is pretty typical of any good Japanese restaurant. 
Scallop Roll- delicious! The texture is soft and melts in your mouth. The roll also tasted very fresh. I would highly recommend ordering this dish!
Agedashi Tofu- a yummy appetizer that is essentially tofu with a fried/chewy layer over it. It's served with soy sauce. 
Green Tea Ice Cream- doesn't this always taste the same everywhere?

The service was also fantastic, although I'm more of a foodie than anything so service tends to be less important for me.
author: Lillian C.

description:
Realistically, I find myself sitting down at Sanraku because it's near my office. Sanraku is A-OK for what I feel it's meant to be: a nicer, restaurant-y sushi place within a reasonable radius of downtown offices for business meetings. It's close, you can sit down and be waited on, it's sushi, case and point, it's an easy choice for office-types needing a place to sit, eat, and discuss. 

I feel fine saying that I haven't had particularly excellent sushi here. That's definitely a plate with sashimi on it in front of me, but man, I just don't taste the love and attention that other sushi places have. The donburi has far too much rice and not enough good stuff. On top of that, everything is a little too pricey. I know that one must be prepared to shell out some extra dollars when one harbors a sushi obsession, but I feel like Sanraku squeezes that notion just a little bit too much. 

On two occasions, myself and a coworker did not receive our orders until our other table mates were finished with their meals. I understand the lunch time rush more than most, but waiting for your meal (for approximately 15 minutes) while your table mates are chowing down is a little painful. Our server was aware of the wait, and I appreciate the attentiveness and the apologies, but when the server has to apologize multiple times.....cringing ensues. 

The food is decent and fresh, the menu has a good selection, the environment is more than comfortable and convenient, but due to my previous service experiences, the seemingly heightened prices, and the lack of "umph" in the dishes, 3 stars I feel is fair. I'll come back, Sanraku, but probably when someone else is footing the bill.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Been coming here once every three months for over 15 years. Excellent for large groups if you reserve ahead. 
Lunch specials are great, and the menu hasnt changed. Excellent service for 15 years - can you beat that? Only a family run establishment like this place could ever achieve that. You never get attitude, you never get bait and switch deals like you do at other more recent Asian food establishments on Folsom and Third streets. Only solid service and a kind demeanor.
While lunch is consistently able to serve the non adventurous and the adventurous, the happy hour delights have scaled back just a wee bit. Bring back the fatty fried chicken skewers! After work hours are fun and the sushi chefs are a lot of fun. 
Terrace/patio dining outdoors with a view of YB gardens is unrivalled in the neighhborhood.
It's a must stop in the SoMa area. Great place to bring out of towners.
author: Nan L.

description:
A mean bento box lunch special! 

I think I paid $12 or miso soup, salad, and a box replete with sesame chicken, grilled salmon, seaweed salad, and three California rolls. Amazing deal for all that food. I will say, the portions were not huge, but just right at about half the size of a normal portion, but you're getting a little of everything here. 

I really liked the sesame chicken, as it was less heavily breaded than what I'm used to, but still crispy enough for that sweet and crunchy affect. 

This place gets pretty busy during lunch, and it's not a huge space, but our server was great and kept our water topped off constantly, and the food was served in a jif!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Most accommodating servers. Food was good but the rolls all started tasting the same. Rolls are 6 pieces so keep that in mind when sharing. 
Crunch roll is different that what you would expect as with the spider roll. I thought the volcano roll was too salty
author: Divine H.

description: Had their sesame chicken, which tasted a little too sweet and heavy on the sauce, but was otherwise good.
author: A L.

description: Went during Dreamforce and surprisingly not crowded, admittedly did go early around 5.  Great service and food was awesome, very fresh and sat at the bar which is always a treat.  Conveniently located and priced right, shout out to the concierge at the Marriott for the tip
author: John T.

description: Was very happy with my dining experience at Sanraku.  Location is great since it is right below the Metreon Movie Theatres.  Everytime I eat here I get enjoy my meal.  It is a bit pricey for a quick Japanese meal at the mall. Loved the Beef Curry Donburi Bowl. Very flavorful very satifying. The Garlic Steak is another favorite.  I got the Matsuri Roll which was spicy tuna, spicy mayo and eel sauce was good, not spectacular a bit expensive but over-all tasty.  Staff is always friendly and polite.  When I tell them I am rushing to make it to a movie they are always accomodating.  The restaurant also has a nice ambiance even if it is right next to the food court.
author: Maria M.

description: I have been there a few times for lunch. Their bento box is a good deal - once I had the salmon bento it was awesome. I had accidentally left my sweater there at one point, and one of their staff came running after me with it so I felt I should give it a shout out - . The california rolls were good. If you are in the area, then this is a decent and fairly nice place to go. They have some outdoor patio seating facing the yerba buena garden.
author: Sofya T.

description: Both Sanraku locations in Soma and Lower Nob Hill are good.
author: Svetlanko I.

description:
Excellent food and service, but awkward location and long wait.

The food here deserves five stars. We ordered sashimi and very basic rolls, and were impressed by the quality. The spicy tuna roll was probably one of the best I'd ever had.

The restaurant is located in a mall, near the food court. It was an awkward location. Also, we had to wait 30 minutes even though we had a reservation.
author: Chris X.

description:
The location is great just outside the metreon.  And the food is a reasonable option to have just before a movie.

Unfortunately the service leaves something to be desired.  (Why is it that it's been two restaurants in a row with this after a string of really good results?) 

Service was ok.  It was relatively prompt, though there was one time that they poured lukewarm water on a refill.  Most importantly, at the end, when we just were about to be on our way we couldn't find our waiter to finalize our bill.  Having seen similar situations out at an airport, we then went out to the receptionist out front.  It was sad she could not handle these sorts of situation without making us feel miserable for wanting to leave in a prompt manner to catch the movie.

As much as I would like to return and as many times as I go to Metreon, it's not worth to be a customer but feel like you're doing them a favor to do it.  Even if it's not a full service sit down service, I think you might feel better at one of those casual, takeout spots nearby.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Sanraku must be the best sushi I have ever eaten in my life. I am from Vienna so I have a disadvantage when it comes to fresh sushi since we dont have an ocean near us. In San Francisco, at least at Sanraku, the sushi really tastes like the fish was caught the same day.

The prices are definitely okay, almost cheap for the quality. I definitely recommend going for the sushi, since the other dishes seem to be only average and youll miss out on that great sushi.

Cant wait to be back in SF to have another load of those great sushis!
author: Andreas R.

description: My boss from my previous job, loves coming here. it's actually quite nice and the place is pretty quiet, so you can carry on a conversation.  located in the heart of downtown you can imagine that it won't be cheap.  The sashimi and the other sushi items are pretty fresh. I had the tempura udon here and it thought the tempura portion was pretty big.  I wonder will this place be here once Target moves in.
author: Belinda C.

description:
To be fair, this place deserves a 3.5 rating.  Sanraku is conveniently located right in the food court of the Metreon.  On a sunny day, you can sit outside and enjoy a Sapporo and sushi.

I've only been here for lunch.  It's a great place to come with co-workers.  We ordered the Gyoza, Chicken Karaage, and a few rolls.  The service is very prompt, and they do a great job at getting you in and out super fast.

If you come here, I would definitely try the Dynamite Roll.  Out of everything we ordered, that one was definitely the best.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Quality of the tuna is questionable. Bone in the imitation crab they put into the dragon roll.  Tempura heavy, greasy, and salty. 

Portions were big....which may not be an advantage with food that tastes like this.

Even the kids were critical.  My seven year old said "if I were a policeman, I would tell this restaurant to make their food better."
author: Todd G.

description: UMMM no bueno, guys. I got the tempura soba. HUGE serving which is surprising I guess for a Japanese place (but I did finish it bc I'm a fatty). However the tempura was hit-or-miss, some were perfectly fried and others were super doughy and soggy. The soba clumped together, which I'd never even seen before in a resto. Think the prices were reasonable, esp for the location.
author: Vivian H.

description: This place is great for the price you pay. We got a variety of rolls, an appetizer, and two miso soups for less than $60. Obviously if you want fancy, top-scale sushi, you can go elsewhere, but if you want good sushi for a good price, this is a great spot. We will be back!
author: Becca C.

description:
Seating was prompt but service was incredibly slow on a Saturday night. The staff was friendly and helpful but they definitely neglected to take my order and deliver it in any reasonable time frame. I sat at the sushi bar and had to wait 30 minutes to get the first piece of fish from the time I ordered. The food was delicious and I would recommend the Uwajima roll (hamachi, cucumber, ginger, scallions) and the scallop nigiri. 

All in all, it was a decent spot for Japanese food if you're in the SoMa area or watching a movie at the Metreon.
author: Victor W.

description: Very average. Good ingredients, friendly but rushed staff. Crowded and rushed. Seating is crammed - that's not their fault all together but just over all average and not pleasant. It's good, not great.
author: Walter K.

description:
Lunchtime sushi, and I got a rice bowl. Ten Don (shrimp and vegetable tempura over rice) for $11 served with a small salad and miso soup. It was a solid meal, filled me up. There really isn't a whole lot more to say about it.

Service is on par, food is quick, the place is clean. If you're in the Metreon and craving sushi or other Japanese dishes, I'd say you'll likely come out of Sanraku feeling the same way I did. It was a-ok.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Yikes, this place was a miss!  For $30 I got the chicken teriyaki plate and a their 'Signature' Ishikari roll to go (and I was UNGRY).  It was a busy Friday night so my food ended up sitting in the bag for 10 minutes before somebody had time to give it to me.

The sushi roll was rather tiny for $12 and full of mayo (yuck!) which the menu claims is "miso sauce."  The chicken breast was more plentiful but quite dry and overcooked.  Highlights: the sparse veggies on the side (three pieces of carrot and a broccoli) were fairly moist and warm, and the bowl of brown rice was fresh, moist, and much better than what they put in the sushi.

Perhaps I caught them at a bad time and/or made bad choices, but even if the food was prepared properly, it would be a pretty poor show for $30.  I saw some of their fancier sushi rolls at the tables and most were covered in mayonnaise.  Perhaps they have decent cuts of sashimi? Don't go here for teriyaki or maki rolls.

I really hate to write a bad review, but there are just SOOO many better options nearby, and I really wish I had gone somewhere else.  For much cheaper and better (but still not great) maki rolls, try Tokyo Express across the street, or Sushi Boat a couple blocks north.  I've also had better (and cheaper) teriyaki at the fast-casual Mr Hana in the Westfield Mall across the street.  And if you really want to spend $30+ at a nice sit-down place, walk a few blocks north to Akiko or a bit further to Ryoko.
author: Paul W.

description:
Mediocre but not bad

After picking up R's friend K from the mass proportion of men from the Game Developers Conference, we steered into the Metreon since it was next door and the rain had started to come down.

We had actually hit Sanraku when it first opened, but I don't think I was on Yelp yet.  Therefore, this most recent visit affords me the opportunity to whip one up immediately.

This may make me sound odd, but I like the fact that when I walk into a sushi/Izakaya establishment, that the wait staff as well as the sushi chefs are speaking Nihongo.  Not to mention the place was packed with attendees from the conference, most still with their badges/lanyards slung around their necks.

The menu here is pretty standard, with typical entrees such as Tonkatsu and Udon, but we elected on several appetizers in addition to rolls:

Poppo Yaki (grilled squid)
Gindara (Butter fish marinated in sakemiso marinade)
Karage
Gyoza
Negihama
Spider Roll
SF Roll

The Squid Yaki was so so......just a charred piece of rubber tire rounds.

The Gindara was amazing and natsukashii, as they state in Nihongo.  Remember that scene from Ratatouille where Anton Ego is whisked away to early childhood experience??  My grandmother use to grill this fish for me during my visits to Japan.....she would marinade the butter fish (so aptly named for it's flakey yet buttery texture....a bit more firm than salmon) in a mix of sake kasu and miso.

The Karage was mediocre as was the gyoza.  The negihama, I personally am not into plain plain rolls unless it was a nigiri.  But the Salmon/Avo roll was good.  The salmon was extremely fresh.

When we rose to go, the sushi chefs spoke Nihongo to our party, although I think they felt the inclination to do so because of K.  HAHA

Food here is slightly more expensive due to the tourists they probably target and the waitstaff quick and efficient.  I might be back, in between movies and stuff.
author: Miika M.

description: I'm sorry, this place is a bust! We are sushi lovers, and we know what fresh sushi should taste like, the sushi here is warm and does not taste fresh! We orders their Uni special and some mixture pieces of sushi, it was runny and warm! Killed our appetite!!! There's lots of sushi restaurants around, I suggest you try others!
author: Tiffany D.

description: This place is excellent! The service is very good and the food is delicious!!! We brought our young children here and they loved it as well. My wife and I both had sushi. We also had some noodle soup with chicken and egg in it. This was a first time try for both of us and it was extremely good! I'd say the only downside is the only beer on tap is Sapporo. Thankfully, I really enjoy Sapporo. I highly recommend this restaurant!!
author: Mark U.

description:
Wow! Incredible. We had went to another sushi restaurant near by Ryokos. Waited a. Hour. Still didn't get sat and decided to go to SanRaku. The sushi melts in your mouth!

Just incredible !! Definitely a must try.
author: Ashley N.

description: Lunches and dinners are pretty reasonable here.  Not many places have such a wide variety in their menu that includes typical Japanese dishes as well as an extensive sushi list.  My favorite is the Sushi Salad, which is on the dinner menu, but you can ask for it at lunch time.  For $20 you get several different types of fish on greens with a vinaigrette.  For $11 you can get one of the lunch specials, my favorite is the Sesame Chicken.
author: Arlene C.

description:
Sanraku is our go to sushi place ever since we moved.  There's nothing fancy about it but it's good and a relatively good deal as well.  We like sitting at the bar and watching them eat sushi.  We've tried all different kinds of the sushi here and have never been disappointed.  The service is good and everyone is really friendly.

I'd definitely recommend checking it out if you're in the neighborhood and want affordable good sushi.
author: Blake B.

description: Our dining experience here was amazing.  Being from Northern Arizona (Sedona/Verde Valley), we have few selections of honestly good sushi.  The service was outstanding, our waitress, Linda was so helpful with the amazing selections of Sake, I never knew there were so many.  We had the Chef's special sashimi sampler...it was amazing.  Never had barracuda or sea urchin but we took a step outside the box and omg, it was fantastic.  The banana chocolate creme brulee was good.  The hit for us really was the sushi.  I read somewhere yesterday, to ask the chef or waitress to surprise you...we did and I want more.  Thank you.
author: Tahona E.

description: This place was delicious! The sushi was excellent. Eating at the sushi bar was a great experience, as you get to watch the chefs prepare the sushi in front of you. The waiter I had was very attentive and helped me decide each time what I wanted and explained things to me I didn't understand. It was a great experience and I would definitely recommend it to others. I got the Philadelphia roll, the Tempura Shrimp roll, and the Golden Gate roll. They were all incredibly delicious. Great experience.
author: John W.

description: I just grabbed a quick bite to eat to go here today, and although I only got one thing (the Eskimo roll), I have to say it was some of the most divine sushi I have ever had. The salmon was incredibly fresh and just melted in my mouth like butter. I'll have to come back here another time for a proper sit down meal!
author: Maya G.

description:
This place in a prime location - whenever I have a movie planned with a friend and more than an hour to eat, this is one of my go-to spots. Their hours are also pretty great since they close at 10pm on Fridays and Saturdays (great for late movies!), and the atmosphere in here is definitely a bit more intimate than the food court (since it is an actual restaurant, and may be the only "restaurant" on that floor). 

The sushi is mediocre like many other yelpers have said. I've tried their rolls and udon as well, and have not been impressed. This place is also somewhere pricey for the quality of food... maybe I'm paying for the convenience of eating in the Meteron instead? 

Until I find another restaurant that's open just as late and has a nice ambiance (with the same proximity to the theatre, (so that I am not late for my movie), this place is A-OK! In my mind, it either this or Mel's drive-in/Denny's, so I'll take this.
author: Lucia C.

description:
I've never had warm dishes here so my comment is strictly for sushi.

I'm a picky Japanese from Japan and I must say Sanraku at Metrion is one of my favorite sushi joints in the city. Sanraku is a part of the food court at Metreon but their food is way beyond food court stuff. 

The fIsh is always extremely fresh.
The chefs were properly trained in Japan.

That's all I ask.
Five stars!!!!!
author: Hide S.

description: Small, busy and harried. Well, what do you expect in the metreon. This place is uber busy and the sushi is fresh enough but not exactly lovingly prepared. I would normally give this place two stars, but they get a little extra points for being reasonably priced and keeping their cool while RSA was in town. You could do worse for lunch.
author: Bill B.

description: Good sushi. Rice bowl was enough for two and ok but chicken was a little dry. Service was excellent. I would come back even though nothing was spectacular.
author: John G.

description:
"Boring"

Would be the best word to describe this place.  Nothing special.  It has food.  You can eat it.  You will probably not come back unless you like an experience that is blah...

Got a few Chef's specials and as it turned out, the Chef makes nothing special.  Naming the food would probably only drive you over to other boring food.  So skip this place.
author: West I.

description:
My husband and I have eaten here without incident for a handful of different dinners, since it is within walking distance from our former home.  While the food was never fantastic, it was perfectly edible as well as reasonably priced for the neighborhood.  So, why the one star rating?

The last time we ate here, they served us some grilled beef that was WELL on its way down the decomposition pathway, and smelled accordingly, despite the heavy-handed application of sauce on top.

Not worth the health risk to eat here again.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Since their recent remodel, this Sanraku location has completely changed -- for the better. They now use the freshest fish and have a great selection of traditional sushi including many hard-to-find items. They have moved their best sushi chef from the Sutter Street location who has developed a complete and imaginative menu. The atmosphere is open and attractive and the staff is friendly and helpful.

I would now put this Sanraku location completely on par with their other location earning them a solid five stars!
author: Kevin K.

description:
I love sushi, I love seaweed salad, but more and more, I'm coming to get really frustrated with Japanese cuisine and being vegetarian. As usual, the options are extremely limited to foods without fish unless you're willing to spend three times as much as everyone else. 

The food is good, I had miso soup, wakame salad and an order of vegetable sushi. Decent, tasty, but ultimately not enough for lunch, I was starving an hour later. 

Doubt Sanraku will be a typical place for me to go for lunch, but I wouldn't write it off for decent Japanese food. It's not my favourite, but it's good if you're in the area and jonesing for some decent sushi.
author: Cassandra J.

description: reasonably-priced items, quick service, and they accept reservations
author: Maria G.

description:
This is the best place in San Francisco for high-quality Japanese food and great service.  The chefs are professionals, and their skill, selection, presentation, and friendliness are unmatched.  The makase-zushi never disappoints.

Also, try the unagi.  It's better than a lot of unagi shops in Tokyo even.
author: Dan D.

description: Great food and service (thank you, Haruna) with outdoor dining on a beautiful day in San Francisco - what more can you ask for.  Had the bento box for lunch. Everything looked and tasted fresh, the delicate flavors well balanced. The miso soup was not too salty as it typically is at other Japanese restaurants. The fried mackerel was perfectly crisp and the chicken teriyaki was just right. And bonus points for refilling my drink before running out..
author: Bailey R.

description:
I ate here few dozens time. I also know the owner, previous manager, and the chef. What can I say? I was a server in this resto once upon a time. Now, ok! you might think I'm bias. That might be true, but let me just inform you what to get and what to skip, okie dokey?! I brought many of my friends here too and so far they like it. Few years ago, I worked around this area, their bento box was a lifesaver. Depending on the day, it can be a hit or a miss. 

Service
So far I have never experience rude service. If the server forgot about certain thing that you asked, just asked again. This resto can be super crazy busy especially during convention time.  

Favorite
You must try their Beef Teriyaki. Ask for extra BBQ sauce on the side to pour on the beef and let them sit, while you poked the beef with your chopsticks (it's okay to play with your food once a while). That's how I eat my teriyaki beef. That way, the meat will soak more sauce. I know, it's weird, but I just like it like that. I also love their steam carrots! Yum! maybe I'll make those tonight myself. 
Their sake (salmon) sushi, salmon skin, CA roll were also tasty, sesame chicken - good, seaweed salad - good (tho I think the 3 different seaweed salad kinda overly priced for the tiny portion), and I missed their miso glazed mackerel/cod/sea bass (was in bento box), tonkatsu - good, Nabeyaki Udon - very good for the cold SF night (dinner menu, but you can asked for lunch too), yakizakana (super fresh!), 
They don't give you soup for your bento if you order it to go. 

Dislike
miso glazed salmon, salmon burger (gross!)

If you order their market price sushi, I always find they gave me generous portion. Love them for that! They also have Happy Hour. I forgot what I had last time, but I thought they were okay. I still prefer Beef Teriyaki tho. If you order combo like Beef Teriyaki and Tempura, you get less beef, but more variety (tempura and beef teriyaki). If you order just Beef Teriyaki, you get more beef. Their tempura is good too, but I'm just not a fan of fried stuff. 

Always asked for what's in bento box for lunch. If there's salmon burger do not order or asked for substitute (they usually don't give you sub, but you can try). This resto keep open between lunch and dinner time, but the lunch menu end at 4pm. Hope this helps!
author: Icey M.

description:
In search of a restaurant that served both sushi and a variety of other Japanese dishes to satisfy children aged 9-50something, we turned to Sanraku. I'm glad we did. It's definitely a good family and group spot, and some of the dishes are well above par. I wouldn't rush back for the sushi, but the other seafood dishes? Awww yeah.

Highlights included the oyster shooter, harami skewers, whole grilled squid, and salmon skin salad. Actually, the salmon skin reminded me a lot of "bacon bits of the sea", but that's awesome in its own right. My personal favorite was the squid, which I would order a thousand times over if given the opportunity, and the exceptionally tender and flavorful harami skewers.

The sushi wasn't as good as some of the sushi I've had in Arizona, which is a red flag considering Arizona is a landlocked prison of resorts and golf courses (has yet to win "raw seafood capital"). It wasn't bad by any means, but there were no ooh's or ahh's designated towards our tiger or rainbow rolls. Nerdy side note: the description for the last roll (rainbow) just read, "seven different things", which we found somewhat hilarious, seeing as every other roll got an actual description and they must've just gotten lazy towards the end.

Overall, I'd say it's worth checking out. Go for the non-sushi seafood items, and order/ship me the squid and a gallon of the sauce while you're there.
author: Rachel R.

description: This is my favorite sushi. They have a great red miso soup, tempura roll, dynamite roll, and green salad. Shinji is THE BEST chef. So friendly and remembers us when we come. Omakase is a great deal for sushi, always the same price but different delicious cuts each time.
author: Tiffany M.

description: Came here for lunch with an old colleague to catch up. She loves sushi as I do as well so I searched for a nice sushi place nearby our workplaces. For a restaurant in a food court, it was very nice. It is inside the Metreon but it didn't feel like we were in a food court. The staff was attentive & very quick service. Clean & to be honest, it is a good spot to go for a casual date. Sushi was great, we started with edamame which was tasty then we ordered the Giants roll, Spicy tuna, Philadelphia roll, 49ers roll & Miso soup which stayed warm the whole time I ate my meal which is a plus for me. It's not the cheapest place to get decent sushi but it is very yummy. I will be back in the future
author: Candice J.

description:
Food = good.  (I enjoyed the yellowtail, sesame chicken, rock-n-roll roll, and some stuff, but I was a tad concerned by the nearly black color of the tuna roll.......)

Service = efficient. 

Decor = simple.  

Prices = moderate.  Happy Hour is okay, if you can figure out which items are actually a better value if you order more than one...;)  (it's 3 to 7 p.m.) Most items are under $5
author: Fannie S.

description: Very rude. I called for a to-go order and they put me on hold for 10 mins. I called back saying I was on hold for 10 mins, all she said was "We're really busy". She didn't even apologize or even try to take my order. I asked if I can order food to-go and she said "you have to hold for a few mins"... This is the worst service I've received in my life. I'm never ever going there. I hate restaurants that treat their customers like dirt!!
author: Sage K.

description:
It has been a thousand years since I have been here at Sanraku!  Overdue for another visit.  This was my go to place for lunch whenever I was at the Metreon checking out the no-it-is-history Sony store.  I would have the sushi and sushi rolls.  

Today was the first Tuesday of the Month at many of the SF museums, including SF MOMA and the Contemporary Jewish Museum.  A new-found BFF and I finally had our get together to check out the Rineke Dijkstra and Mark Bradford exhibitions.  Both were very impressive.  We plan on coming back next month for a revisit.

Lunch was BFF's treat.  My BFF wanted to have lunch and was open to any suggestions I had.  We decided to go for inexpensive Japanese.  We were walked to see if Sanraku was still in business and Voila!  We had about a 10-15 minute wait.  It did not seem that long, we were almost seated immediately.  BFF had ordered the salmon teriyaki filet and I had the tempura lunch.  Both were worth the price and so delicious.  BFF offered part of her salmon filet and I let her take whatever she wanted of my tempura.  The tempura was quite delicious, four prawns and mixed veggie served with steamed rice.  I was quite impressed with the salmon teriyaki filet.  BFF also shared her salad with me, which was quite nice. I must have been really hungry, I ended up eating her rice too.  She did not want it.  And for dessert, we each had a scoop of green tea ice cream.  I was impressed with the color, it was green tea macha.  

The service was good, yet busy.  We came in-between the lunch rush, so it took a little while, not too long, to place our order.   The Computer Game Development Conference was taking place at the Moscone Center.  Our server and a manager checked in to see how we were doing.  Most of all, they kept my water glass filled.
